ZnSe-WO3 nano-hetero-assembly stacked on Gum Ghatti for photo-degradative removal of Bisphenol A: Symbiose of adsorption and photocatalysis
Amit Kumara*, Mu Naushadb, Anamika Ranaa , Inammuddinc, Preetia, Gaurav Sharmaa, Ayman A. Ghfarb, Florian J. Stadlerd, Mohammad R. Khanb
*aSchool of Chemistry, Shoolini University, Solan, Himachal Pradesh, India-173229

Graphical abstract
Abstract:
In this research work we report Gum-ghatti supported ZnSe-WO3 nano-hetero-assembly for solar powered degradation of endocrine disruptor Bisphenol S (BPA). The photocatalyst was characterized by Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), Small area electron diffraction (SAED), X-Ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infra red spectroscopy (FTIR), Photoluminescence (PL), Energy dispersive Xray (EDX), UV-Visible spectrophotometry and Brauner Emmet Teller surface area analyzer (BET). We achieve a Z-scheme photocatalyst (ZnSe-WO3) with a higher charge flow and visible absorption. Gum ghatti acts as a superadsorbent and a sink for charge carriers. The removal of BPA has been studied under three experimental protocols where 99.5% removal was achieved by symbiose of photocatalysis-adsorption-ozonation in just 45 min. hetero-assembly
has a high surface area, stability and reduced carrier recombination. The results have been analyzed by scavenger effect, mass spectrometry, kinetics and total organic carbon (TOC) analysis. 49.4 % of TOC was removed and COD was reduced to 16.7% after 2 hr in symbiotic condition. From the band edges and scavenger effect it was inferred that superoxide radical anions are major attacking species. The work paves way for designing of novel photocatalysts with increasing biogenic quotient and higher efficiency.
Keywords: Hetero-junctions, bisphenol, photo-degradation, adsorption, Gum ghatti, ozonation

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Environmental pollution and energy issues are one of the crucial issues for human society that we are facing today in this century [1]. Increased industrialization had lead to severe environmental contamination via persisten and toxic pollutants. Contaminants of emerging concern as pharmaceutical effluents, phenols, pesticides, fungicides, phthalates etc. have led to degradation of soils and water bodies because of untreated discharge. Various endocrine disruptors as 17-β-estradiol and Bisphenol A (BPA) etc. have attracted concern [2]. Bisphenol A (2,2-bis(4-hydroxyphenyl) propane, BPA), is known for its strong estrogenic activity and extensively used in polycarbonates, epoxy resins, flame retardants, etc.[3-4]. BPA can increase the activity of macrophages, decrease antibodies and cause immune disorders and pathology. Due to the excessive discharge of waste water or improper disposal of landfill leachates, BPA has been ubiquitously found in aquatic environment [5], with high concentrations up to 8 lg L-1 [6]. Current technologies as adsorption and coagulation merely concentrate the pollutants present by transferring them to other phases. However the pollutants still remain and are not being completely “eliminated” or “destroyed”. Heterogeneous photocatalysis and ozonation have proved to be efficient tools for eliminating organic contaminants in wastewater [7]. Photodegradation has been one of promising techniques due to its high mineralization efficiency, low toxicity, low cost, and ability to perform under ambient conditions [8].
Recently Biopolymer based photocatalysts and adsorbents have gained importance [9-11]. The biopolymer adds to the biogenic quotient of the photocatalysts, provides support, decreases recombination and thus acts as sinks for electrons [12]. Gum polysaccharides (Gg) are organic molecules that occur in a variety of natural sources with many hydroxyl and carboxylate functionalities. Gum ghatti has wide application as superabsorbent and as flocculent for the treatment of waste water [13]. Gg acts as support for the heterojunctions and increase efficiency of the heterojunction by enhancing surface area for the photodegradation process.
Semiconductors suffer from drawbacks as electron-hole recombination. To tackle this problem polymer support, doping and formation of heterojunctions are the best used methods. The unique heterojunction can significantly reduce the recombination of the photogenerated electrons and holes which improve the photocatalytic properties of the products. The coupling of two different semiconductors does not only improve quantum yield, but also changes photo-absorption range of semiconductors. Designing of novel heterostructured materials with a cost effective and efficiency approach has been a challenging task. [14]. Synthesis of heterojunctions with appropriate positioning of conduction bands and valence bands could lead to reduced recombination of charge carriers [15-17]. Thus overlapping of band edges at interface promotes the charge transfer and higher light absorption. [18]. Many biomolecules supported metal oxides as chitosan-GO [19], chitosan-TiO2 [20] and hetero-junctions as ZnO-TiO2 [21], TiO2-Cu2S [22] and ZnO-ZnSe [23] have been used for removal of pollutants via adsorption and photocatalysis.
ZnSe had evolved as the most promising photocatalytic material with a band gap of 2.7eV at room temperature [24-25] and large excitation binding energy of 21 meV. Recently the nanostructures of ZnSe have received much attention due to its photocatalytic activities. Recent studies showed that these ZnSe nanostructures not only exhibit good photocatalytic activities but they also possess the absorbing edge of visible light. As it possesses a narrow band gap it can be easily excited by the visible light. Formation of the ZnSe-WO3 not only enhances the absorption of solar light but also efficiently separates photogenerated charge.
Another important metal oxide, tungsten oxide, WO3, is a n- type semiconductor having a small band gap of 2.6 eV [26] having enormous properties including electrical, optical, thermoelectric and physiochemical properties. Due to these wide ranges of properties in various fields it has
tremendous use in chemical and selective catalysis, sensors, fuel cell, chromism and photodegradation of pollutants [27-28].
Herein we report a Gum ghatti supported nano-heterojunction of WO3 and ZnSe for solar powered degradation of Bisphenol A. In this work role of adsorption in photodegradation has been studied under different experimental protocols.

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials
sections.text: All chemicals used in present research were of AR grade. Sodium Tungstate (Na2WO4.2H2O), Cetyl Trimethyl Ammonium Bromide (CTAB), Hydrochloric acid (HCl) , Zinc Nitrate hexahydrate Zn(NO3)2.6H2O, Sodium Selenite (Na2SeO3), Sodium Borohydride (NaBH4), Sodium hydroxide flakes, Tungsten oxide(WO3) and Gum ghatti were acquired from Sigma Aldrich and used without further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2 Synthesis of WO3 nanoparticles
sections.text: WO3 nanoparticles were prepared by CTAB surfactant assisted synthesis. 1.5g of sodium tungstate and 0.26g of CTAB were suspended in 30 ml of distilled water under constant stirring. The pH was adjusted to 3. The resulting precipitates were washed with ethanol and then vacuum dried at 50 °C. The powder was then sintered at 600°C for 4 h.

sections.heading: 2.3 Synthesis of WO3/ ZnSe hetero-junction (WZ)
sections.text: 0.2g of zinc nitrate dihydrate, 0.03g of sodium selenite and 1.5g of sodium borohydride were dissolved in 25 ml of distilled water with constant stirring. Sodium hydroxide solution was then added. This was followed by the addition of tungsten oxide (500mg). The WO3/ZnSe composite thus prepared was filtered and then washed using the mixture of absolute ethanol and distilled water.

sections.heading: 2.4 Synthesis of WO3/ ZnSe /Gg hetero-junction (WZG)
sections.text: WZ was synthesized as described as above with addition 1g of gum ghatti. The WO3/ ZnSe /Gg composite were filtered and then washed using the mixture of absolute ethanol and distilled water. The powder was then vacuum dried at 50 °C.

sections.heading: 2.5 Characterization
sections.text: The crystal structure, phase purity and grain size of nanocomposites were obtained using an XPERTpro X-ray diffractometer. The FTIR spectra of nanoparticles were recorded with the KBr pellet method using a Nicolet 5700 FTIR spectrometer. The SEM micrographs were taken with a LEO 435 VP instrument. A FEI Tecnai F20 transmission electron microscope was used for the high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images. The ultraviolet-visible spectra (UV-vis) were recorded using a Systronics 2202 double beam spectrophotometer. Total surface area was measured using N2 sorption on a NOVA 1200 analyzer and calculated using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method.

sections.heading: 2.6 Optical studies
sections.text: To compute band gap studies, a 0.005 g photocatalyst suspension in ethanol was prepared. The suspension was then ultrasonicated for 2 h. The UV–visible spectrum was then recorded using a Systronics-2200 double –beam spectrophotometer. The direct band gaps were then calculated using the Tauc relation. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were obtained at room temperature with a PerkinElmer LS 55 spectrometer with excitation wavelength of 320 nm.

sections.heading: 2.7. Removal of BPA
sections.text:
The photocatalytic ability of the photocatalyts was tested by solar powered degradation of Bisphenol A (BPA). The tests were done under three set of experimental protocols. In protocol 1: The slurry (100m L) containing photocatalyst (50 mg) and BPA (10 mg L-1) was kept in a double wall cylinder with water circulation, placed on a magnetic stirrer as represented in Figure 1(a). The area of experiment is Solan, Himachal Pradesh, India- 30.904ºN, 77.096ºE in the Western Himalayan region. The experiments were performed in the month of April with average intensity of sunlight as 30 × 103 ± 100 lx. The solution was first kept in dark to establish adsorptiondesorption equilibrium. The solution was then exposed to sunlight. In protocol 2: the slurry was
directly exposed to sunlight for simultaneous adsorption and degradation. In protocol 3: the slurry was directly exposed to light and ozone gas was passed. The ozone required for the process was produced from dry oxygen in a laboratory ozone generator. The absorbance was recorded using a double beam UV–visible spectrophotometer (Systronics 2202).
GC–MS analysis was carried out with a Thermo Scientific TSQ 8000 gas chromatograph–mass spectrometer. After 20 min of degradation process solution was centrifuged and the intermediates were extracted using 5 mL of dichloromethane. Intermediates were then diluted by a mixture of 1:1 acetonitrile and water. The separation was performed on a Betabasic C18 column (150 mm X 2 mm) with a mobile phase flow rate of 0.5 ml min-1.
The total organic carbon TOC was determined by total organic carbon analyzer (TOC 5000 analyzer, Shimadzu, Japan) .The fall in chemical oxygen demand (COD) was analyzed by the closed reflux method using potassium dichromate as the oxidant under acidic condition.

sections.heading: 2.8 Reusability
sections.text: To check the efficacy and reusability of photocatalyst for the photo-degradation of BPA were performed for 6 continuous cycles.

sections.heading: 3.1 FTIR Studies
sections.text:
FTIR spectrum of the ZWG is represented in Fig 1(b). The FTIR results confirm the formation of WO3/ZnSe/Gg and WO3/ZnSe nanocomposites. The peaks at 3417cm-1 corresponds to O-H stretching (carbohydrates) and at 2928cm-1 is due to –CH2(asymmetric stretching).
In addition 520.9 cm-1 refers to pyranose ring in gum ghatti and at 1450cm-1 is due to –OH in plane bending [29]. The set of peaks between 710-800cm-1 corresponds to W-O-W stretching , at 910cm-1 and 962 cm-1 refer to combined to effect of O-O stretching and vibration of peroxo group and W-O-W stretching of bridging oxygens [30]. The band at 486 cm-1 assigned to the ZnSe stretching vibrations. This confirms the succesfull formation of composite.

sections.heading: 3.2 X- ray diffraction studies (XRD) analysis
sections.text: The XRD pattern of WZ and WZG are given in Figure 2(a) and (b) respectively. In the XRD pattern of WZ the peaks at 2θ= 27.340, 45.700, 53.820and 72.500 correspond to (111), (220), (311) diffraction planes of ZnSe corresponding to fcc cubic structure which are in well agreement with JCPDS file 80-0021 [31]. The peaks at 230, 24.230, 26.490, 34.000, 41.560, 48.190, 55.710, 62.110 and 76.280 refer to (001), (200), (120) , (220), (121), (221), (240), (132) and (422) diffraction planes of WO3 corresponding to monoclinic structure and are in agreement with JCPDS file 05-0392 [32]. The lattice constants are a = 5.670 Å for ZnSe and a= 7.312Å, b= 7.621Å and c= 7.836Å for WO3. The crystallite size for WZ is 20-26nm. The XRD pattern of WZG is given in Figure 3(b). The characteristic peaks for WO3 and ZnSe are present with some of peaks missing due to dominance of Gum ghatti matrix. The average crystallite size for ZWG is calculated as 27-34nm.

sections.heading: 3.3 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis
sections.text: The SEM images of WZ and WZG are given in Figure 3(a) & (b) respectively. WO3 nanoparticles have a rod like shape while ZnSe are spherical. It is clear from the SEM images that the WG photocatalyst has a uniform spherical shape. In the SEM images of WZG we see a higher hierarchy because of dominance of gum-ghatti. The surface morphology has also changed. WO3 and ZnSe nanoparticles are uniformly distributed over the gum ghatti matrix.

sections.heading: 3.4 Transmission electron microscopy analysis (TEM)
sections.text:
TEM images of WZG at different resolutions are represented in Figure 4. The average size of particles lies between 25-30nm. Figure 4(a) and (b) show low resolution images of WZG. The WO3 nanorods and ZnSe nanoparticles can be seen uniformly dispersed in the gum-ghatti matrix.
The darker portions represent WO3 and ZnSe counter parts and grey portion represent gumghatti. Higher resolution images of WZG (Figure 4c) shows the crystalline inorganic part. The SAED pattern (Figure 4d) shows that the composite has a crystalline nature.

sections.heading: 3.5 BET studies
sections.text: Figure 5(a) represents N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for surface area determination. The specific surface area of ZWG is 301m2/g. The Gum ghatti matrix provides high surface area and support to the ZW junction making it a better adsorbent and photocatalyst

sections.text:

Thus we expect a higher visible region absorbance. The optical band gap of bulk WO3 is 3.0 eV and 2.70 eV for ZnSe. The band gap of WO3 is decreased in nano formwhich may be due the crystal defects induced during synthesis process. However in case of ZnSe we achieve the same band gap in both the forms.

The band gap parameters are listed in Table1.
The WO3 and ZnSe form a staggered gap type of semiconductor hetero-junction. On absorption of solar light electron-hole pairs are generated for both the semiconductors. The electrons from
conduction band of ZnSe (-0.68eV) get transferred to CB of WO3 (0.22 eV) and similarly holes from VB of WO3 (2.72eV) to less positive VB of g-ZnSe (2.02eV). Thus vectorial transfer of charge carriers takes place. This leads to a charge separation, increased transport of carriers and a reduced recombination [34].Gum ghatti provides support to the ZW junction and prevents agglomeration.
Figure 5 (c) shows the PL spectrum of ZnSe, WO3 and ZWG. The photoluminescence peak ~430 nm is refers to luminescence of the ZnSe [35]. For WO3 the emission peaks appeared at ~ 418 nm and ~525 nm are observed [36]. However the peaks are nearly absent in PL spectrum of ZWG as curve becomes nearly flat. This confirms the successful formation of hetero-junction and reduced charge carrier recombination. The EDX pattern of ZWG is given in Figure 5(d) which shows peaks for C, O, Zn, Se and W. This confirms the formation of WZG.

sections.heading: 3.7.1 Adsorption and photo-catalytic degradation of BPA under solar light
sections.text:

The adsorption data is also represented by Langmuir adsorption isotherms. The Langmuir model is given by Eqs (4)

Langmuir isotherm model is for monolayer adsorption. In this case the adsorption of BPA and onto ZW and ZWG (Figure 6b) follow Langmuir model with both KL (0.0119) and and RL (0.912) hinting towards favorable model and adsorption. The maximum adsorption capacity for BPA is 72.22 mg/g and 48.64 mg/g for ZW and ZWG respectively. The higher adsorption of BPA onto ZWG is due to high surface area of GG and functionality available which leads to binding of pollutant onto photocatalyst surface.
The photodegradation of BPA under protocol 1 is given in Figure 6(c). BPA is highly stable, as plain photolysis under sun leads to only 2.9% degradation. 95.6% of BPA was degraded by
ZWG in 2 h and 71.4% by ZW. The photo-catalytic degradation of BPA at pH = 6 was tested in presence of ZW and ZWG under solar illumination. Figure 6(d) shows the performance of photocatalysts for BPA photodegradation under protocol 2. It was noticed that a degradation of 82.5% and 99.2 % was achieved in presence of ZW and ZWG respectively in a 90min experiment. During symbiotic adsorption and degradation better results are obtained. The general mechanism is given in schemes 1 and 2.
In a typical process the ZWG exposure to solar light leads to formation of electron-hole pairs in both the semiconductors. These then react with oxygen and water to form reactive oxygen species as *OH, *O2-, *OOH etc which lead to disruption of conjugation and mineralization thereof [37-38]. The O2- react with H+ to form hydrogen peroxide radicals (•HO2) (scheme1) which leads to formation of hydrogen peroxide. Hydrogen peroxide is a better electron acceptor than oxygen and reduces the chance of oxygen recombination [39].
The plain photolysis of BPA under solar light (Figure 6d) shows a mild degradation of 4.3% which indicates the stability and persistence of the pollutant in water system.
It is observed that the degradation results are better in case of ZWG under both the reaction conditions which is due to two reasons- firstly ZWG has a lower band gap and secondly the gum ghatti matrix provides support to the junction and a higher surface area. This facilitates higher adsorption and better photocatalysis. In general it is assumed that the rate of photodegradation is highly enhanced by the adsorption of the pollutant onto the photocatalyst. The total concentration of organic pollutant (BPA) at any time is [17]

In protocol 1, the rate of degradation falls after some time because of the fact that most of surface has been covered by BPA, thus hindering the photo-activity of catalyst. Thus there is possibility that the surface of photocatalyst gets covered by BPA and so degradation gets suppressed in subsequent time. However in protocol 2, the pollutant is degraded as soon as it gets adsorbed. Thus sites remain available for further adsorption. The photocatalytic photo catalytic efficiency can be enhanced by adsorption of adsorbate onto the catalyst [14, 33]. Gum ghatti provides sufficient sites for adsorption or binding to BPA.
This leads to the reduced recombination or electron-hole reconciliation. In addition the band gap
of WZ and WZG lie in visible region which enables higher solar absorption. Figure 7 (a) shows the formation of heterojunction. The CB of WO3 is 0.22eV) and ZnSe is -0.68eV.The redox potential of E(O2/*O2-) = -0.33 eV) which is closer to CB edges of ZnSe. Thus superoxide radical anions can be generated. The standard redox potential of top valence band WO3 (2.72eV) is higher than E(*OH/H2O) (2.27 eV vs NHE) [40], facilitating production of hydroxyl radicals from water. In a similar way the VB edge of ZnSe (2.02eV) is higher than redox potential E(*OH/-OH) (1.99 eV vs NHE) [41]. Thus photo-generated holes are thus capable of producing hydroxyl radicals both from hydroxyl ions and water. The pictorial representation of the three experimental protocols is given in Figure 7(b).
Figure 8(a) shows the removal of BPA under experimental protocol 3. 98.2% of BPA was degraded in presence of ZWG in just 45min of exposure. The simultaneous photodegradation was assisted by radicals produced by dissolved ozone. The reaction scheme in presence of O3 is given in scheme 3:
The pictorial representation of the three experimental protocols is presented in Figure 7(b). If we compare the three experimental protocols it is observed that in adsorption followed by photo catalysis, satisfactory results are obtained but the rate of reaction is slow. In protocol 2 the simultaneous adsorption and degradation increases the rate of degradation many folds as pollutant is degraded as soon as it is adsorbed on ZWG. Thus sites remain available for next pollutant molecule. In third experimental protocol, ozone passed through slurry leads to formation of more hydroxyl radicals and also leads to better charge separation via reduced recombination. More reactive species lead to higher degradation and a faster reaction.

The kinetics plots are for degradation of BPA by ZWG is given in Figure 8(b). The rate constants and half life periods are listed in Table 2.In presence of ZWG the apparent rate constants for BPA degradation are 0.0276 min-1 and 0.0464 min-1 and 0.0905 min-1 under experimental protocol 1, 2 and 3 respectively. The kinetics plots for WO3, ZnSe and ZW for degradation of BPA (protocol 1&2) are given in Figure 8(c) & (d). It is clear that the photodegradation is multitimes fast in presence of ZWG under protocol 3. In case of ZW hetero-junction the electrons from CB of ZnSe migrate to the CB of WO3. Similarly the holes from VB of WO3 migrate to VB of ZnSe by vectorial charge transfer. For further insight into the major attacking reactive oxygen species, the role of radical scavengers was tested.

sections.heading: 3.7.2 Effect of pH, H2O2, ions
sections.text:
The working pH of degradation in this experiment is 7. Figure 9(a) shows the effect of pH on degradation of BPA under symbiotic process in presence of ZWG. We obtain highest degradation in pH range 5-6. The results are poor at highly acidic and basic conditions. The polarity of ZWG photocatalyst was determined using dynamic light scattering in pH 5-6 and 7-8. The surface of ZWG is nearly neutral charged in pH range 5-7 and negative in higher pH range. The pzc of ZWG is 6. The pKa value for BPA is 9.5. At working pH=7 (higher than pzc) the surface of ZWG is negatively charged and that of BPA is positive which facilitates the binding onto sites. This is represented in scheme 3. At lower pH the surface is slightly protonated and repels the BPA molecule. However at higher pH both the catalyst and the pollutants will be negatively charged and thus decrease the adsorption. At very low pH BPA will be protonated and it could also lead to leaching of the photocatalyst. At very high pH both the BPA and ZWC are negatively charged which doesn’t favor the interaction. Thus the degradation is decreased at highly acidic and highly basic conditions.
The effect of H2O2 and NO3- on the photodegradation of BPA in presence of ZWG is given in Figure 9(b). With increasing the concentration of hydrogen peroxide the rate of degradation
increases with achievement of almost completer degradation in less than 45 min. This is because of the fact that hydrogen peroxide is a major source of hydroxyl radicals. However in case of NO3- ions the degradation is increased for 1mM concentration but rate falls at higher concentration (5mM). Nitrate ions which are normally present in water act as a major precursor for •OH under solar light [42]. However at higher concentration, nitrate ions would compete with the pollutant and thus decrease the degradation process.

sections.heading: 3.7.3 Reactive species and Mechanistic pathway
sections.text:
Batch experiments were also carried out to have an insight into mechanistic degradation pathway. A series of oxidation-reduction reactions take place and in addition to electrons, holes, reactive oxygen species as *O2- ,*OH etc. are generated. To study the role of various species effect of scavengers as KI (as hole scavenger), [43] Benzoquinone (BQ) (*O-2 scavenger) [44] and Iso-propanol (IPA) (*OHads) [45-46] on degradation process in presence of ZWG under symbiotic system was studied. Fig 9(c) shows the effect of scavengers on degradation of BPA for experimental protocol 2. The degradation falls to 13.4% in presence of BQ and to 59.3% in case of IPA. The fall in degradation shows that superoxide radical anaions as well as hydroxyl radicals participate in the process. Decrease due to IPA shows that hydroxyl radicals are responsible for degradation of BPA [47]. However it is clear superoxide radical anions are more active. These facts are also supported by the band edges and the redox potential for the ROS generation. The mechanism of scavengers in given in scheme 5:
Figure 9(d) shows the effect of scavengers on protocol 3. In presence of ozone hydroxyl radials are formed as per scheme 3. I t was observed that during photo-ozonation the rate is decreased in presence of IPA but KI and BQ has a smaller effect. This confirms the participation of *OH as major active species. Our results are consistent with previous findings [48]. Ozonide radical formed (•O3−) reacts with H+ in the solution leading to HO3• radical which then decomposes into •OH. Alternatively, Ozone scavenges electrons and holes then again react to form hydroxyl free radicals. The synergy between photo-ozonation and catalysis leads to higher results because of better charge carrier separation, and higher ozone decomposition.
3.7.4 TOC/COD removal & Reusability
The effect of scavengers and band structure analysis suggests a mechanistic pathway of degradation of BPA. The results are analyzed in terms of TOC, COD analysis. The TOC and COD removal are represented in Figure 9 (e). In presence of WZG, 49.4 % of TOC was removed and COD was reduced to 16.7% after 2 hr in symbiotic condition. This suggests mineralization of BPA. Based on the intermediates detected in GC-MS spectrum (reconstituted) (Figure 9(f)) a degradation pathway is proposed in scheme 6. The intermediates are listed in Table 3. In a typical mechanism •OH radicals may attack BPA to produce phenol, Bisphenol E (m/z=216), phydroxyacetophenone, 2-butenoic acid, p-hydroquinone, 4-isopropenyl phenol (m/z=122) etc may lead to mineralization in form of simple moieties as acetic acid (m/z=60), ethanol, oxalic acid (m/z=90) carbon dioxide [49] etc.
The reusability studies of ZW and ZWG for six cycles are given in Figure 9(f). The results show that both the catalysts are stable and reusable for many cycles as the degradation falls to a very small extent after repeated use. The fall in activity is due to covering of the catalyst by the pollutant molecules which leads to reduced solar exposure. The photocatalyst is separated magnetically from aqueous system.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions:
sections.text: Gum-ghatti supported nano-heterojunction WO3/ZnSe was developed for endocrine disruptor BPA removal. The biomaterial –metal oxide-selenide heterojunction in its low dosages is efficient in photo-degradation of BPA because of higher charge separation and reduced recombination. Gum ghatti matrix provides support, surface area and adsorbent base and sink for charge carriers. The degradation process was studied under three experimental protocols achieving 99.5% of BPA degradation in just 45 minutes under protocol 3. The identification of fragments, band structure analysis has led to prediction of plausible reaction pathway of BPA and mineralization. The photocatalyst was reusable for 6 consecutive cycles with decent photoactivity. This laboratory scale experiment paves a way for designing of biopolymer based heterojunctions with correct band positioning for efficient solar powered degradation of other contaminants of emerging concern.

metadata.abstractText: In this research work we report Gum-ghatti supported ZnSe-WO3 nano-hetero-assembly for solar powered degradation of endocrine disruptor Bisphenol S (BPA). The photocatalyst was characterized by Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), Small area electron diffraction (SAED), X-Ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infra red spectroscopy (FTIR), Photoluminescence (PL), Energy dispersive Xray (EDX), UV-Visible spectrophotometry and Brauner Emmet Teller surface area analyzer (BET). We achieve a Z-scheme photocatalyst (ZnSe-WO3) with a higher charge flow and visible absorption. Gum ghatti acts as a superadsorbent and a sink for charge carriers. The removal of BPA has been studied under three experimental protocols where 99.5% removal was achieved by symbiose of photocatalysis-adsorption-ozonation in just 45 min. hetero-assembly
